learning_outcomes.description: music techniques objectives - Demonstrate understanding of the concepts of common-practice harmony through analysis and music writing;
music techniques objectives - Successfully analyse common-practice tonal music in various idioms and formats using relevant methods;

music techniques objectives - Complete various music writing tasks including harmonising given soprano or bass lines in four-part style, realising figured bass in keyboard style, and working with other simple formats;

music techniques objectives - Complete writing tasks as in 1.3 above in accordance with the principles of common-practice harmony, observance of correct part writing, phrase structure, cadences, functional progressions, control of dissonance, idiomatic consistency, etc.;
music techniques objectives - Render the items above in simple keyboard work.
Aural skills objectives - Demonstrate fluency and command of a set repertoire for this course;
Aural skills objectives - Analyse and communicate the pitch and rhythmic structures of selected repertoire;
Aural skills objectives - Sing, play and notate familiar and unfamiliar musical material;
Aural skills objectives - Demonstrate accuracy, confidence and fluency in all tasks;
Aural skills objectives - Demonstrate the ability to work creatively on all tasks; and
Aural skills objectives - Engage critically and reflectively with methodologies used for aural studies.

assessments.task_description:
Practical Work for the Aural Musicianship component of MUSC2060 is in two parts. Each part is worth 20% of the final grade for the course. Full details will be provided in class with ample preparation time. Below is a summary of the requirements:


Part 1 (due Thursday Week 8):

  • Perform a given simple time rhythm including irregular groupings and ties while keeping the beat, in time, without the aid of a metronome
  • Sing the Ionian, Lydian and Mixolydian modes while keeping the beat and an ostinato
  • Sing and play one of the given canons at the keyboard
  • Video an ensemble performance of a canon not performed for the tasks above

Part 2 (due Friday Week 11):

  • Perform a given  compound time rhythm including irregular groupings and ties while keeping beat, in time, without the use of a metronome
  • Sing all the modes in note names and solfa in tune from the same starting note while keeping the beat and performing an ostinato
  • Sing and play one of the given canons at the keyboard
  • Video an ensemble performance of a canon not used for the tasks above.
  • Sing a third canon while accompanying yourself at the keyboard using the left hand for the bass notes and using appropriately voiced chords in the right hand. 


Submission of both parts of the Practical Work is through the assignment links provided in the MUSC2060 Blackboard site. Work is to be submitted in the form of identity verifiable audio-visual recordings.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be be submitted online through Blackboard
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
• Rhythmic Dictation in simple time
  • Rhythmic dictation in compound time
  • Interval dictation
  • Melodic dictation in major including chromaticism from the tonic Mixolydian and Lydian modes. 
  • Two-part melodic dictation in minor with possible chromaticism from the Dorian and Phrygian modes. 
  • Harmonic dictation including inversions and suspensions. 


This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Not a submissible item, takes place during class time.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
As progressive assessment during semester, students must complete a total of three worksheets. 

Worksheets will be made available progressively through the semester. 


Worksheets contain questions and tasks related to current course content but also require students to demonstrate ongoing accumulation of skills and knowledge based on previous work in this course and MUSC1600 (or equivalent).


Worksheets include keyboard tasks which will be submitted as a video component.


Each worksheets is worth an equal portion of the 30% set aside for this component of assessment. 


This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.


Due dates for worksheets are as follows:

  • Worksheet #1: 5.00pm, Tuesday Week 4
  • Worksheet #2: 5.00pm, Tuesday Week 8
  • Worksheet #3: 5.00pm, Tuesday Week 12

assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
A final, take-home assessment for the Tonal Harmony / Keyboard component of the course will be issued in Week 10. The work set will require students to harmonise a chorale melody in SATB style, showing mastery of specific materials covered in weeks 1 to 10 (and, by implication, on-going mastery of the materials of MUSC1600), by following the methods outlined in the final two weeks of semester. Students are also required to perform the soprano and bass lines of their completed work on keyboard.


This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Review

Topics students should know from MUSC1600; basic principles and rules of "SATB" and "keyboard" styles; Roman-numeral and figured-bass nomenclature; "Why study SATB?"—relationship of SATB to "real" music; the vertical and horizontal dimensions of SATB (harmonic vs contrapuntal model)


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Review Topics students should know from MUSC1600; basic principles and rules of "SATB" and "keyboard" styles; Roman-numeral and figured-bass nomenclature; "Why study SATB?"—relationship of SATB to "real" music; the vertical and horizontal dimensions of SATB (harmonic vs contrapuntal model)

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1

Major and all minor scales; major triads in root, first and second inversion sung from common starting notes; review of simple and compound time; partwork


Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1 Major and all minor scales; major triads in root, first and second inversion sung from common starting notes; review of simple and compound time; partwork

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Harmonic progressions

The phrase model; classification of chord progressions by root motion; harmonic functions, simple expansions of a single harmonic function.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Harmonic progressions The phrase model; classification of chord progressions by root motion; harmonic functions, simple expansions of a single harmonic function.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2

Lydian and Mixoydian mode, modal transformation of simple repertoire; natural and harmonic minor triads in root position, first and second inversion; ties within bars; rhythmic performance, rhythmic dictation


Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2 Lydian and Mixoydian mode, modal transformation of simple repertoire; natural and harmonic minor triads in root position, first and second inversion; ties within bars; rhythmic performance, rhythmic dictation

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Second-inversion chords

General principles of the 4th as a dissonance; cadential six-fours; dominant vs. tonic function; passing six-fours; expansions of a single function; other six-fours—auxiliary, arpeggiated six-fours


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Second-inversion chords General principles of the 4th as a dissonance; cadential six-fours; dominant vs. tonic function; passing six-fours; expansions of a single function; other six-fours—auxiliary, arpeggiated six-fours

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3

Dorian and Phrygian modes, modal transformation of simple repertoire; suspensions — 2,4,6,9; ties across bars; melodic dictation


Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3 Dorian and Phrygian modes, modal transformation of simple repertoire; suspensions — 2,4,6,9; ties across bars; melodic dictation

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Non-chord tones; suspensions (part 1)

Dissonance and resolution (general principles); rhythmic characteristics (strong/weak) and dissonance control; review of passing and complete neighbours (accented and unaccented); incomplete neighbours (appoggiaturas, escape tones, etc.); introduction to suspensions


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Non-chord tones; suspensions (part 1) Dissonance and resolution (general principles); rhythmic characteristics (strong/weak) and dissonance control; review of passing and complete neighbours (accented and unaccented); incomplete neighbours (appoggiaturas, escape tones, etc.); introduction to suspensions

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4

Locrian Mode; minor chords from the melodic minor notes (raised 6th); irregular groupings (triplets/duplets); two-part melodic dictation


Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4 Locrian Mode; minor chords from the melodic minor notes (raised 6th); irregular groupings (triplets/duplets); two-part melodic dictation

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Suspensions (part 2)

Suspensions over root-position triads (4-3, 9-8, 7-8); suspensions over first-inversion triads (7-6); bass suspensions in first-inversion triads (2-3); embellished resolutions


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Suspensions (part 2) Suspensions over root-position triads (4-3, 9-8, 7-8); suspensions over first-inversion triads (7-6); bass suspensions in first-inversion triads (2-3); embellished resolutions

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5

7th chords naturally occurring in major; hemiolas


Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5 7th chords naturally occurring in major; hemiolas

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Problems of harmonisation in minor keys

Harmonic vs. melodic minor (general principles); raised submediant and subtonic as non-chord tones; raised submediant and subtonic as chord tones (chords IV, ii6, v6, VII and III); the augmented triad (III+) in minor


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 6: Problems of harmonisation in minor keys
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Problems of harmonisation in minor keys Harmonic vs. melodic minor (general principles); raised submediant and subtonic as non-chord tones; raised submediant and subtonic as chord tones (chords IV, ii6, v6, VII and III); the augmented triad (III+) in minor

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6

Secondary dominant 7th from chord ii using the Lydian note fi to prepare the dominant; inversions of the dominant 7th; irregular metres 5/4; harmonic dictation


Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6 Secondary dominant 7th from chord ii using the Lydian note fi to prepare the dominant;	inversions of the dominant 7th;	irregular metres 5/4; harmonic dictation

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Diatonic seventh chords (other than V7)

Predominant 7th chords; tonic seventh chord; leading-note seventh chord in minor keys; leading-note seventh chord in major keys


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Diatonic seventh chords (other than V7) Predominant 7th chords; tonic seventh chord; leading-note seventh chord in minor keys; leading-note seventh chord in major keys

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7

Secondary dominant 7th chord from I using the Mixolydian note ta to prepare the subdominant; irregular metres 7/8; basic keyboard accompaniment


Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7 Secondary dominant 7th chord from I using the Mixolydian note ta to prepare the subdominant; irregular metres 7/8;	basic keyboard accompaniment

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Secondary dominants

Tonicisation; tonicisations of the dominant; tonicisations of the subdominant; tonicisations of other triads in major or minor keys; cross (or false) relations


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Secondary dominants Tonicisation; tonicisations of the dominant; tonicisations of the subdominant; tonicisations of other triads in major or minor keys; cross (or false) relations

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8

Use of fi and ta as signposts for possible modulations to the dominant and subdominant in major


Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8 Use of fi and ta as signposts for possible modulations to the dominant and subdominant in major

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Modulation

Relatedness of keys (circle of fifths); relative strength of tonicisation (modulation vs. secondary-dominant progressions); common-chord modulation; sectional modulation; modulation by chromatic alteration.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 10: Modulation Relatedness of keys (circle of fifths); relative strength of tonicisation (modulation vs. secondary-dominant progressions); common-chord modulation; sectional modulation; modulation by chromatic alteration.

Consolidation; specific content TBA

Learning outcomes: L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L11

Catch up week for revision of any concepts before the final two weeks (chorale harmonisation)

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Putting it all together part 1

Complete chorale harmonisation; analysis of melodies (identification of tonality, phrase structure, cadence types, structural harmonies/functions); construction of bass lines; harmonic interpretation of bass/soprano structure; addition of inner parts; elaborations of texture

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
